awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: Decision-Making Processes for Resilient Tourism-Based Economic Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the turn of the 21st century, tourism has experienced exponential growth due to the increasingly interconnected nature of the world and the relative ease of travel. According to the United Nations World Tourism Organization, tourism is now one of the world’s fastest growing industries. Since the inception of tourism studies, a majority of research has focused on the positive economic benefits of the industry, overlooking the widespread negative economic, social, and environmental impacts. Similarly, studies have often focused on tourism from the perspective of consumers in developed countries.  Tourism research that does focus on host destinations in developing countries are rare and also typically limited to the perception and attitudes of hosting residents.  Research has not been focused on the decision-making processes of destination stakeholders.  Globally, households in regions with high levels of tourism, particularly those invested in tourism-based livelihood strategies in rural areas, are rapidly diversifying their livelihoods to tourism-based ones.  This research will investigate the social, cultural, economic, environmental, and institutional factors influencing their decisions to do so.
  
This research project explores the livelihood and management decisions of stakeholders by drawing from the theoretical frameworks of complexity and commons theory and integrating this thinking with existing tourism literature. The research will be carried out in the Himalayan region of Upper Mustang, Nepal, a region particularly relevant because of dramatic infrastructural changes and its recently being opened to tourism in 1992. Pilot work in the area in 2018 and 2019 suggests that households are rapidly diversifying their livelihoods, resulting in an exponential increase in tourism activities since 2007. Using surveys, semi-structured interviews, and participant observation, this research will first investigate local inhabitants’ decision-making processes, regarding whether and how to engage in tourism-based livelihoods. Second, the research will engage elected officials to understand their decision-making processes in developing and managing tourism. This research contributes to transitioning and reframing tourism studies within broader interdisciplinary scholarship - one which considers tourism to be a set of choices open to people among other livelihood and management options linked to other social, cultural, and environmental outcomes. In addition, this research has the potential for real-time practical, institutional, policy, and managerial impacts, which will be valuable for effective management of tourism in the study region, as well as other tourist destinations facing difficult institutional and governance decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the assistance of this Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG) from the NSF, Tashi Wongdi Gurung (PhD Candidate in the School of Human Evolution and Social Change at the Arizona State University) was able to collect data in the region of Upper Mustang, Nepal. Before the advent of COVID-19, tourism was one of the world's largest and fastest growing industries, leading households in tourism regions to diversify their livelihoods or transitioning to tourism-based ones. While both hosts and consumers (i.e. tourists) feel the impacts of tourism, the literature predominantly tends to focus on consumers. The decision-making processes of various stakeholders to engage in tourism (or not) in host destinations are comparatively understudied and undertheorized. This project was developed after pilot research was conducted in 24 villages in Upper Mustang during the summers of 2018 and 2019, which indicated that 90 percent of the participants would transition to a tourism-based livelihood if they had the resources. The broader focus of this dissertation is to examine the core facets of tourism impact and benefits, while incorporating caste and history-driven power relationships. Additionally, this research aims to understand the decision-making processes and examine the underlying behavioral rationale of these tourism-based livelihood decisions.



The DDRIG funding was used for fieldwork. The original data collection timeline was obstructed by a global pandemic COVID-19. As such, data in Upper Mustang, Nepal was collected in the year 2021 across 24 villages. With the help of a local research assistant, data collection started in July 2021 and concluded in November 2021. A mixed-methods approach was employed, including a survey questionnaire (n = 134) with open-ended follow up questions, participant observation, and a census of hotels and ownership. The results of the study show that the perceived impacts of tourism were primarily dictated by geographical location, specifically the communities' centrality to trekking routes and level of interactions with tourists. The uneven distribution of tourism benefits was attributed to power relationships emerging from historically established social structures that predate tourism itself. Caste and history-driven power relations were identified as significant factors that shape the distribution of tourism benefits and impact on local communities. Data analysis focusing on the decision making dynamics of the individuals/households, in conjunction with a multi-level lens in Upper Mustang in the context of tourism-based livelihood diversification employing Sustainable Livelihood Framework, is at a preliminary stage. 

 

The DDRIG has led to the production of several academic works. The DDRIG has aided in the publication of one article titled "The co-production of disasters: how the nexus of climate change, tourism, and COVID-19 increases socioeconomic vulnerability in Mustang, Nepal?" in the journal Critical Tourism Studies. In addition, an article titled "An Un(Even) Playing Field? A Political Ecology of Tourism Impacts in Upper Mustang, Nepal?" has been submitted to the journal of Tourism Planning and Development and is currently sent out to reviewers for peer review. Furthermore, the data collected during the DDRIG research period has been disseminated through several public talks with the local communities and academic conferences in the USA and across the globe. 

 

This research creatively and originally integrated theoretical frameworks from various disciplines. The findings of this research provide a key empirical case that contributes to the broader literature on the nexus of institutions, migration, livelihood decisions, and tourism. This research is at the intersection of livelihood diversification, tourism, and institution and contributes to the reframing of tourism studies. A layperson's version of the findings will be disseminated to all elected officials and local communities. The broader impacts of this research extend beyond informing better-informed livelihood decisions for locals to also include better management of tourism by elected officials. The recommendations based on the findings of this research will be offered to government and related organizations, which are instrumental in policy decisions and implementations. This research is taking place during a major political transitions in Nepal and therefore, has the potential for real-time practical, institutional, policy, and managerial impacts which will be valuable for effective management of tourism not only in the region of Upper Mustang, but in other Himalayan regions of Nepal and other Himalayan countries.
